item.title: Turkish and Greek fighter jets collide over Aegean Sea
item.description: A Greek pilot is feared dead after his fighter jet collided with a Turkish rival and crashed in the Mediterranean. Each country is blaming the other for the incident.

item.title: Home by Christmas? Make that 2010 at least
item.description: The first British soldiers who deployed to Iraq immediately after the 2003 invasion thought that they were going to be the last troops to be sent and hoped they would be home by Christmas.

item.title: British troops in Iraq for another four years
item.description: Tony Blair has reached agreement with Iraq's new prime minister on the phased handover of control to civilian authorities which could see British troops stationed there for a further four years.

item.title: Grief over innocent victims of Israeli missile
item.description: Israel has announced it would hold an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding a missile attack which has wiped out three generations of an innocent family.

item.title: Montenegro takes place as Europe's newest nation state
item.description: Europe gained its newest nation as the tiny Balkan state of Montenegro voted to split from Serbia, marking the final break-up of the former Yugoslavia.

item.title: The killing goes on
item.description: There has been no let up in the violence in Iraq as at least 17 people were killed in a series of car bombs and shootings.

item.title: Shia hardliner on a mission to hold his despairing nation together
item.description: When Iraq's Shia parties first proposed Nouri al-Maliki as a possible candidate for the post of Iraqi prime minister, few thought that Washington or London would accept him.

item.title: Commons sketch
item.description: Commons Sketch by Andrew Gimson.

item.title: Abandoned in the 'death zone'
item.description: Mark Inglis, the double amputee who conquered Everest last week, has defended his party's decision to carry on to the summit despite coming across a dying British climber.

item.title: No 1 banana could face extinction
item.description: The most popular type of banana, the Cavendish, is under threat from disease.

item.title: $90,000 found in politician's freezer by FBI
item.description: The FBI has discovered $90,000 (£47,000) wrapped in aluminium foil inside the freezer of a senior Democratic congressman.

item.title: Banks join US curbs on Iran
item.description: The Bush administration has persuaded four of Europe's largest banks to start breaking off contacts with Iran as Washington pushes for anti-Iranian sanctions by "the back door", it has emerged.

item.title: Tory fears over deal on defence spending
item.description: Britain will be obliged to account for its actions if it fails to spend enough on defence equipment made within the European Union.

item.title: British take on Taliban in five days of Afghan fire-fights
item.description: British troops have engaged in fire-fights with Taliban insurgents for the first time since deploying in Afghanistan, it has emerged.

item.title: 16 civilians die in US strikes near Kandahar
item.description: An American air attack on Taliban positions in southern Afghanistan early yesterday morning resulted in the deaths of at least 16 civilians.

item.title: Oprah's record book deal over battle of bulge
item.description: Oprah Winfrey, a self-confessed compulsive eater, has signed the biggest non-fiction book deal in history to write about her battle with the bulge.

item.title: Call for the army to halt Aborigine gang wars
item.description: Gang warfare between rival groups of spear-wielding Aborigines is so serious in some outback towns that the army should be sent in to restore order, the Australian government has been told.

item.title: Burma's inhuman jails condemned
item.description: A catalogue of fatal abuse of political prisoners in Burma has been disclosed in a report released, with detainees beaten to death, held in appalling conditions, and deprived of medical care.

item.title: Tibetan honour for Hergé
item.description: The late Belgian cartoonist Hergé is to be honoured by the Dalai Lama for making "significant contributions to the public understanding" of Tibetan culture 50 years after writing Tintin in Tibet.

item.title: Stone treads warily to put Sept 11 on the big screen
item.description: Hollywood is rarely known for its restraint, but it has decided that the first feature film to depict the September 11 attacks on New York will not use footage of the two planes exploding into the Twin Towers.

item.title: Why England's team is in mint condition
item.description: A small town in northern Germany claims to have come up with the "smell" of the World Cup by gathering together the "scents" of the football teams to compete in next month's tournament.

item.title: 'These days Chinese cyclists won't be seen dead on a Flying Pigeon'
item.description: One of the most iconic symbols of old China - the sturdy, gearless black bicycle ridden by the masses - is running out of customers in Lycra-clad, mountain-biking modern China.

item.title: We thought of hacking off our legs, say miners
item.description: Two Australian miners who survived a 14-day ordeal trapped under rubble deep in a collapsed mine have said that they had considered cutting off each other's legs with small knives and had written farewell messages to their families on their own skin in expectation of dying.

item.title: We thought of hacking off our legs, say miners
item.description: Two Australian miners who survived a 14-day ordeal trapped under rubble deep in a collapsed mine have said that they had considered cutting off each other's legs with small knives and had written farewell messages to their families on their own skin in expectation of dying.

item.title: Iraqi cabinet sworn in to a thunder of bombs
item.description: With bomb blasts thundering outside the building and arguments raging inside, Iraq's new parliament approved its first ever national unity government - urging a message of "love and tolerance" that its own members broke almost straightaway.

item.title: Bones in togas puzzle Vatican archaeologists
item.description: Archaeologists who have explored one of Rome's oldest catacombs have been baffled by neat piles of more than 1,000 skeletons dressed in elegant togas.

item.title: No let-up in bombings as new cabinet takes over
item.description: A fresh wave of suicide bombings in Baghdad has underlined the challenge facing Iraq's new government as the prime minister vowed to use "maximum force against terrorism".

item.title: Montenegro is divided over vote to separate from Serbia
item.description: The Balkan state of Montenegro has voted on whether to become independent from Serbia and write the final chapter in the break-up of the former Yugoslavia.

item.title: New Orleans backs disaster mayor
item.description: Ray Nagin, the mayor of New Orleans criticised for his reaction to Hurricane Katrina, has been re-elected in a dramatic comeback.

item.title: Seven die in Muslim 'suicide attack' on Kashmir rally
item.description: Islamic militants have hurled grenades and fired assault rifles into a ruling Congress Party rally in Indian-administered Kashmir, killing at least seven people, including two policemen and injuring another 22.

item.title: How the rot set in for Blair's reputation
item.description: For Tony Blair the conflict in Iraq resembles a debilitating disease. The onset was devastating and the patient has been sickly ever since. The damage done to his reputation for integrity can probably never be reversed.

item.title: Bush's popularity falls casualty to the war
item.description: War made George W Bush's presidency and now it looks like destroying it with barely 30 per cent said they approved of Mr Bush's handling of the war.

item.title: The long road back to independence?
Why England's team is in mint condition
item.description: A small town in northern Germany claims to have come up with the "smell" of the World Cup by gathering together the "scents" of the football teams to compete in next month's tournament.

item.title: Farm search for Hoffa's remains
item.description: The FBI was engaged in a huge search for the remains of Jimmy Hoffa, the infamous union boss linked to the Mafia.

item.title: Hamas official caught with £450,000 hidden in clothes
item.description: Rival Palestinian forces have been involved in a stand-off at Gaza's border crossing with Egypt after a Hamas official was caught with €639,000 (£450,000) hidden in his clothing.

item.title: 'Mudcat' sets sights on rural America
item.description: A gun-loving, stock-car racing-mad country boy, Dave "Mudcat" Saunders has to be America's most improbable Democratic consultant.

item.title: Consumers braced for Merkel's tax rises
item.description: German consumers were bracing themselves for the highest tax increase since the Second World War after parliament voted in favour of a controversial rise in VAT.

item.title: US diplomats alerted over Chinese computers
item.description: American diplomats have been instructed not to keep classified material on 16,000 newly purchased computers because the manufacturer is partly-owned by the Chinese government.

item.title: Pope sacks Church leader over sex abuse
item.description: Pope Benedict has taken disciplinary action against the Mexican founder of the Legionaries of Christ, ordering him to renounce every public duty after a nine-year investigation into claims of sexual abuse.

item.title: Orthodox church is consecrated in Rome
item.description: The first Orthodox church to be built in Rome since 1054 has been consecrated in another sign of improved relations between the Vatican and the Patriarchate of Moscow.

item.title: North Koreans 'ready to test missile that puts US in range'
item.description: According to officials in South Korea and Japan, who have seen satellite intelligence photographs of a launch site, North Korea may be preparing to test a missile capable of reaching America.

item.title: Taliban commander 'captured' by Afghans
item.description: Afghan forces have claimed to have pulled off a major victory by capturing the Taliban's leading military commander.

item.title: Life in jail for Costa killers of tortured Britons
item.description: Two Venezuelans who tortured and murdered a British couple at a remote Spanish villa have each jailed for more than 50 years.

item.title: Gun-death aristocrat threatened by minister
item.description: A government minister in Kenya has threatened to take the law into his own hands if police release Tom Cholmondeley, the white aristocrat arrested last week for shooting dead a trespasser.

item.title: The week at a glance
item.description: In the past week special constable Nisha Patel-Nasri was stabbed to death with her own knife, financial stock markets across the globe were shaken by fears that rising inflation would force up interest rates and Sir Paul McCartney announced the end of his four-year marriage to Heather Mills.

item.title: Britons deployed as 100 killed in Taliban clashes
item.description: More than 100 people died as Taliban fighters and Afghan forces clashed in the fiercest fighting since British troops arrived in southern Afghanistan last month.

item.title: War in Iraq was 'grave mistake,' says Prodi
item.description: Romano Prodi, Italy's new prime minister, has pledged to pull Italian troops out of Iraq, saying that the war had been a "grave mistake".

item.title: Life in jail for Costa killers of tortured Britons
item.description: Two Venezuelans who tortured and murdered a British couple at a remote Spanish villa have each jailed for more than 50 years.

item.title: Bush immigration reforms fail to reassure patriots
item.description: President George W Bush has taken his proposals for immigration reform to the south-western tip of the Arizona desert where illegal smuggling, accompanied by crime, banditry and death, is soaring.
